title: The Cell Membrane
description: Explore the structure and function of the cell membrane. Learn about the phospholipid bilayer, fluid mosaic model, and how membranes control what enters and exits the cell.
learningIntentions: Explain the fluid mosaic model of membrane structure
Describe the role of phospholipids and membrane proteins

engagementHook.title: The Gatekeeper
engagementHook.content: Your cells are surrounded by a barrier just 7 nanometers thick—10,000 times thinner than a human hair. This fragile membrane decides what enters and exits, keeping you alive by blocking toxins while letting nutrients through.

contentSections.title: The Phospholipid Bilayer
contentSections.content:
The cell membrane is composed of a phospholipid bilayer. Each phospholipid molecule has:

  • Hydrophilic heads: Water-loving, phosphate group, face outward
  • Hydrophobic tails: Water-fearing, fatty acid chains, face inward

This arrangement creates a barrier that water-soluble substances cannot easily cross. The tails form an oily core that repels charged molecules while allowing small nonpolar molecules to pass through.

contentSections.title: Fluid Mosaic Model
contentSections.definition: A model describing the cell membrane as a fluid combination of phospholipids, cholesterol, and proteins that can move laterally within the membrane. The 'mosaic' refers to the pattern of proteins embedded in the lipid bilayer.

contentSections.title: Membrane Proteins
contentSections.content:
Proteins embedded in the membrane perform various functions:

Integral Proteins

  • Span the entire membrane
  • Act as channels or carriers for transport
  • Include receptors for cell signaling

Peripheral Proteins

  • Attached to membrane surface
  • Function in cell recognition and signaling
  • Can be easily removed

contentSections.title: Cholesterol and Membrane Fluidity
contentSections.content:
Cholesterol molecules are scattered between phospholipids and help maintain appropriate membrane fluidity:

  • At high temperatures: Cholesterol restrains phospholipid movement, preventing excessive fluidity
  • At low temperatures: Cholesterol prevents packing, maintaining fluidity

This temperature buffering is essential for membrane function across varying conditions.

contentSections.title: Clinical Connection: Cystic Fibrosis
contentSections.content:
Cystic fibrosis is caused by a defect in the CFTR protein—a chloride channel in the cell membrane. When this protein doesn't function correctly:

  • Chloride ions cannot exit cells
  • Water follows by osmosis (reduced)
  • Mucus becomes thick and sticky
  • Lungs and digestive system affected

This demonstrates how critical membrane proteins are to health.
